answers.author: Michael Repas
answers.text:
Hi Milton:
I have looked into this, and found some success stories, as well as signs that several other local governments are considering this as a possibility as well.  In all of these cases, I have posted the articles directly on the Knowledge Network for your ease of use!
In terms of success stories with light rails, there are several cities in Florida which have had great success in making the naming rights available for sale; it started with a streetcar system in Tampa, and then this success spurned a similar action by the Miami-Dade Transit System.  There has also been a successful agreement in Philadelphia, PA that is worth mentioning.
-The report done by Front Row Marketing about the streetcars in Tampa is available here: http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/301449/Tampa_Historic_Streetcar_Sponsorship__Endowment_Program_Evaluation_Analysis
-A report on both of the naming rights sales:http://icma.org/en/Article/100427/MiamiDade_Transit_selling_Metromover_station_naming_rights
-The AT&T Station renaming in Philadelphia, PA: http://icma.org/en/Article/100428/Heading_to_game_Stop_at_ATT_Station
The city of Cleveland, OH has also found success in selling naming rights to a new bus line operated by the Rapid Transit Authority (RTA) of the city.  It is named the Health Line, and this name was decided by the two sponsors that approached the RTA – the Cleveland Clinic and the University Hospitals are paying a combined total of $12 million for the naming rights.  Read more about it here: http://icma.org/en/Article/100426/Clevelands_Health_Line_Setting_a_National_Example_for_Bus_Rapid_Transit
There are also several cities considering the possibility of selling the naming rights of their light rail systems, which might be worth looking into for you as well:
-A proposed light rail system for Detroit, MI: http://icma.org/en/Article/100424/Light_Rail_System_Proposed_for_Detroit
-The possibility of $29 million in revenue for Norfolk, VA and its light rail system: http://icma.org/en/Article/100425/Norfolk_could_reap_29M_for_lightrail_naming_rights
-The Port Authority of Pittsburgh, PA is considering a similar program: http://icma.org/en/Article/100429/Port_Authority_considers_naming_rights_for_its_properties 
I hope this helps!

text:
I am posting on behalf of Milton Dohoney, City of Cincinnati.  
Milton is seeking contacts engaged in naming rights consulting and negotiation related to streetcar or light-rail projects.  If you have been involved in a project like this and have any contacts or success stories, please share.     
Thanks,
Thomas
